text: [Music] i'm looking forward to following up here with the first two presenters and sort of bringing in um just a kind of some practical extension uh perspectives to this i also want to thank my original co-author and co-presenter of the first version of this presentation safely utilizing animal manures and compost on small produce farms and its perspective here from montana so you know montana is known as cattle country we're primarily a cow-calf state but we do have some beef back grounding and finishing some dairies and some hog kafos so we do have animal production systems where manure is collected um but all counties in our state do have sufficient conventional crop ground relative to manure nutrients uh to to agronomically utilize those resources while we may have some high areas of nutrient concentration within a county within a region of the state this can easily be remedied with nearby export of those manure nutrients so where are they going well the top bullet points here all the common places that you know many of us have worked with management planning and nutrient management planning and whatnot so just moving manure and manure products to conventional crop and forage ground a lot of our nutrients from manure in the state get processed compost and go to reclamation projects so usually some sort of mining reclamation project could go to organic row and or forage crops turf and green industries you know your sod farms and nurseries and whatnot uh utilize a fair amount of our exported or manure nutrients exported from the site of origin and then finally sort of the new and emerging opportunity [Music] driven by you know interest in local food systems across the country but in our montana communities as well that opens the opportunity to move manure to small produce farms and market gardens this some images here sort of demonstrate the the use of those manure based products and this is at our student-run organic farm which is actually also a retail farm but in this image we see the importance of bringing manure in manure-based compost to renovate soils and then also provide for ongoing fertility so this compost here was mostly beef manure from a research scale but conventional beef feeding facility and it's being incorporated into soil under this movable high tunnel and a quick comment these high tunnels are really important to us for vegetable production in montana uh you see this one day here where they're working in the area and then the image on the right we see snow piled up from a late spring snow storm so these high tunnels make small veg small scale vegetable production possible in montana uh we have noticed um social barriers related to the exchange of nutrients from the animal ag industry to market gardens um and that represents you know missed market opportunities for moving manure nutrients into another sector or helping better balance local nutrient balance and such and we're hoping to solve this just through more facilitation and education both by extension and government agencies and a lot of the concern or the social barriers you know it's just based around well the important concern over food safety perhaps concern over herbicide residues passing through the manure and the compost and then concerns over implications for organic certification and real quick i want to point out a case study about a pretty interesting unconventional farm a mafia organic dairy primarily raises dairy goats and then they have their own cheese plant but in all of their waste management cycles and whatnot they also have other enterprises they have some pastured pork and they have an organic vegetable enterprise so they manufacture compost and it's mostly used for their on-site animal feed crops and that's a bunch of organically certified uh crop feed crop ground they also use the the compost back into their organic vegetable enterprise and then they also sometimes engage in occasional compost sales but they are moving these nutrients through multiple enterprises on their farm everything is certified organic in this case and then the image shows some of their compost working areas so the most raw stuff here is in the foreground and these uh bigger windrows there's some curing piles and windrows back here a finishing screen and then there's another storage area not in that image where the finished compost is stored separate from all of the raw and manure and compost working areas um we've mentioned already the previous two speakers brought forth uh fisma and uh don't need to speak too much about it now or again i should say but just to remind everybody that it does focus on prevention of food safety issues and though the rules are supposed to be science and risk based as we've heard just recently we recognize that additional research can provide further guidance and understanding of the risks involved and then potential policy adaptations so on the practical advice side this is what andrea my colleague at montana department of agriculture and the produce safety program she likes to call it her musts and shoulds lists all right and this is really pulled from the different rules and recommendations but um an operation a produce operation under fisma must know must store and convey manure and compost so that they do not impact or interact with the produce covered by the rule food contact surfaces and processing areas areas used for any other fisma or produce safety rule covered activities should not interfere with or interact with water sources and water distribution systems you know we heard earlier how irrigation water can be a potential conduit for pathogens from manure to produce and then any other soil amendments you don't want the raw manure or unfinished compost products to interact with or possibly contaminate other soil amendments should practices this is getting down into little more details about how you might accomplish those musts so you should keep raw manure and finished compost in separate areas like i explained previously with the a mafia dairy example they have three different compost and soil amendment working in storage areas so you have that that gap in that distance you should designate specific equipment and tools for dealing with soil amendments and uh you know raw versus treated amendments and then when you must have or need to have shared equipment then you should have a cleaning and sanitation program when that equipment moves from dealing with a raw type soil amendment to another purpose on the farm particularly anything that would be closer contact with the actual produce more should steps to prevent this cross-contamination at the you know small farm level or any farm really limit access and traffic around all the soil amendment areas that includes humans farm animals nuisance animals and scavengers equipment any any sort of traffic or movement around the farm you want to be storing uh these place these materials in such a way that uh regular traffic is not going to cause cross-contamination um and then just like we would manage manure and compost storage on any size operation you want to use best management practices um for pollution prevention around these storage areas as well so appropriate storm water management runoff or leachate capture and management if necessary and these would all be you know best management practices appropriate to the climate environment and other state and local rules usda good agricultural practice standards also overlap along with these woods or shoulds shoulds and musts that we talked about from fisma and some of this is very similar once again so looking at treated over non-treated [Music] soil amendments of manure origin the right application timing and considering the extending those harvest intervals that were discussed the 9120 the application method handling and storage we spoke about that just two slides ago in more detail and then record keeping about the management of manure compost composting processes and all of the soil amendments used as far as organic certification there's some other you know best practices or due diligence we've already discussed 9120 with crops contacting the ground and crops that may be above the ground but also the issue that we've dealt with a lot here in montana as manures from animal agriculture have moved into this small produce sector um is the issue of ag chemical residues in that manure compost and so this is just going to come down to producer due diligence to make sure that those types of residues are not going to impact their production [Music] and then as always when we're talking about an organically certified operation you know you should work with an expert certifier as you communicate with farmers and make sure anything they're doing or adding is okay on the nop list of approved products so there are a variety of players here in montana that are working with producers with the produce safety rule in the national organic program that's really led in the state by montana department of agriculture we have a state certification program there are other organic certifiers in the state but they play a large role in assisting producers and maintaining their certifications while using the types of products we're learning about today as far as regulatory education that also happens from our montana department of agriculture as well as extension both in agriculture and in foods and nutrition and then trade organizations as well are important conduits for education on this topic to our growers and then as far as just good agricultural practices and all around best management practices a lot of the same folks are involved there but also some of our producer co-ops are involved in educating producers and helping manage all of this for growers that may be a member of say this example co-op so in summary manure and compost are valuable nutrient inputs for small produce farms they are not generally prohibited but we rely on best practices and rules to reduce the risk of some sort of contamination and a foodborne illness and that just comes down to proper management as discussed today and in general everything we talked about here the best practices and um you know these rules it focuses on preventive measures over widespread sampling and testing of the food products so this is an upfront preventive management you know set of recommendations and programs that we've discussed here today um instead of you know actual widespread sampling and testing of all the produce produced you
